reviewText:
I'm not quite sure how I feel about this game yet. It feels like it is still in early access, and can use some work, but theres a lot of potential. As a full game though as it is right now, I would not recommend it.
The controls seem slightly delayed, and are sloppy. Jumping is a huge issue, as well as running.
You tap slightly to make your character move and NOT fall off, and your charater doesnt move. So you hold down for slightly longer, and your character goes flying off the sign.
I've died so many times because I hit spacebar to jump and because of the delay, the character doesnt jump, just runs straight off the sign. It is very frusturating and unrewarding. You have no control over your jump, once you jump your charatcter will jump at whatever speed you were running at, and you have no control of the jump while in the air. So quite often you'll jump from a sign right into the abyss.
The idea of the game in general is very creative, but as a platformer, there are much more polished games out there you can get for a cheaper price.
The controls are just so sloppy that it ruins the game for me. I'd recommend this game once the controls are fixed.
voteText: 125 of 177 people (71%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Nice little platformer. I reviewed this game a while ago, and gave it a negative review – based on its original controls, which made the game unplayable for me. A few days ago, the developer Midnart contacted me, informing me that the game has been patched, including the controls. So I gave it a second chance – and I am glad I did. The game is now controlled smoothly and after beating it (which took me, I do not know, 2 – 3 hours maybe? ) I can see its other positives:
- Good atmosphere – from tense moments like running from poisonous gas, through adrenaline riding moments to overall melancholic feeling of the game (loved the end – no one left behind :) )
- Fine music fitting the game
- Clever puzzles – some of the puzzles seemed frustrating at first, but once you realize the principle of solving them, you will feel a sense of accomplishment (at least I did) – the puzzles are based mostly on perceiving the physics of the environment and interaction with it
- Stylish graphics – although minimalistic (based on sign infographics), they serve their purpose and benefit the game

The game is basically one continuous trip (not classic levels) with checkpoints on the way. The one negative that comes to mind is its length. On the other hand, if you want to spend an evening or two with something interactive (rather than watching stupid movies), Sign Motion is a good alternative.

reviewText:
Not worth $10
* Uninspired platforming gameplay
* Jumping/running controls handle like a shopping cart, straight up ignores jump inputs / keeps moving forward after letting go
* Continually makes you repeat the same boring platforming sections if you mess up (which you will mainly due to aforementioned rancid platforming.
* Graphics/audio are meh

Summary: if you want a decent 2D platformer gameplay go play one of the mario / sonic's, not this. If you want quirky indie platforming/puzzle solving, go play braid or limbo, not this.

Keep away.

reviewText:
It's a 2D puzzle platformer. With Limbo sort of gameplay but equally as nice. Was quite surprised by this game as i wasn't expecting it to be this good. The game is very simple yet can be challenging at times. A stick figure in the land of road signs and must keep going. I liked the puzzles and sound is very relaxing. The graphics are as you would expect a 2D sidescroller to be like.

It's not that long, took me 2 hours to beat the game and get all the achievements.

Nice pricetag of $10 and probably will be cheaper during sales too. Get it if you like puzzle platformers.

reviewText:
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
Overall Rating: 10/10
Gameplay Rating: 9/10
Accessibility Rating: 10/10

Overall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and accessibility (how the game includes deaf/hoh gamers).

General GameplaySign Motion is an extremely creative 2D scrolling puzzle/challenge game that begins when events throw your character's sign out of its normal existence.

You play as a stick figure, either male or female (changed in settings), that traverses across of signs from throughout the world.  The signs in the game provide clues as to what puzzles or challenges you will face, ranging from sliding cars to falling rocks, explosive crates, and poisonous gas that chases through through a large portion of the game.

Your progress is saved after each major puzzle or challenge and, if you 'die,' you restart at the most recent save point, ready to begin the challenge again.

Although the game is not overly hard, it provides a hint system for the slightly more complex challenges that explains in three individually revealed images how to pass the challenge.

There are a few visual treats in the game as you go along, including indicators for how much is left to travel before you finish by way of US destination milage signs.

Sign Motion is ultimately a game on level with mobile or console gaming that was ported to PC.

Replayability
All in all, Sign Motion is a really cute, creative, fun game that will entertain you for a few plays.  Realistically, you could get 2-3 fun iterations of this game before you've successfully completed all of the challenges without issue.


General Accessibility
Accessibility Options
Options are limited in the game, which is a design for both console and PC games.

For HoH gamers, you can choose volume between master volume controls, game sounds, and game music, allowing you to tune according to what is best for you.

As a side note for mobility challenged gamers, this game uses either A and D or left and right arrows to move forward and backward, left control to push/pull objects, and space to jump.  These keys cannot be changed.

Subtitles & Captions
This game can be complete and enjoyed entirely without sound, so no captions are needed or provided.

Chatting/Communicating
This is a single player game; no chatting.

---
Visit Games Reviews for the Deaf/HoHhttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/gamereviewsforthedeaf

reviewText: I came to this game at the recommendation of a friend, who knew I enjoyed puzzles.  I typically like games like World of Goo, Diner Dash, and other casual games but when I saw the preview, I was intrigued. reviewText: Sign Motion Is a great little puzzle platformer that in my view deserves more credit than what it has gotten in the overall reviews. reviewText:
It's a great game, but it needs a few improvements:

-A save/load/level select system
-Better physics (sometimes my character got stuck on a ramp and I had to jump repeatedly to move at all)
-Customizable controls
-A bit more checkpoints
-More sound

I would recommend this to anyone looking for a great game, but I'm also hoping that an update will be released for it to fix a few things.

reviewText:
Impressive and unique game made by a single person - respect. It's the story of the kid who escaped from the school crossing sign.You can choose if you want to play as a girl or a boy - I would suggest a girl - you can use the ponytail to tell what direction your character is facing.
The music flows with the game and really completes the immersive experience. The character design reminds me of Limbo and Deadlight - you're a shadow in a moderately colorful surroundings. The whole world of this game is composed out of all kinds of street signs - and when in doubt what to do - always check the signs in the background - is the way the game gives you hints.
The game mechanics are pretty simple - run around, you have a jump that's heavily influenced by momentum, and you can pull/push things around. The physics of the game can get frustrating at the time (or maybe that's just me), but produce a very unique gameplay in comparison to other puzzle platformers.
The game progression is separated in street signs, that represent the different levels and, as long as I can count correctly (as you can choose your starting point in the menu), there are 32 levels in the game. The level length is very different (as your street lengths are very different :) and as far as I can tell (my progress is 18/32) there are no checkpoints, so failing can get somewhat frustrating in the longer levels.
The game introduces new mechanics every now and then and keeps the gameplay interesting - from tough jumps to driving a motorcycle, gliding in the air or getting chased by a poisonous fog - and those are just the ones I've experienced, who knows what the future levels hold.

I'm not sure how I feel about the price tag, maybe wait for it to go on sale.
TL:DR or want to see some gameplay - check out my first impressions video
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=331109340

reviewText: This game is odd in the way that it could have been so good. The music, atmosphere, and ideas surrounding the plot are great. The controls and level design fall short.  It's a 3-hour long platformer that will frustrate you when your inputs are ignored. You cannot adjust the game volume (there's an option, but as soon as you exit it re-adjusts back to the default setting: blow your speakers). The puzzles are very easy to figure out, but sometimes difficult to do because of shoddy controls, or time-limits. Both of which are a platforming no-no in my world. It feels awkward to control at times, funky things happen that (I'm assuming) shouldn't, like getting stuck on corners of platforms instead of landing on top of them or climbing them which the controls call for. For the 75% off price I bought it at, it's worth it; about two bucks. At the full price, it's not worth it. I urge this programmer to make a sequel and focus on controls and level design, because this idea really could be amazing.

reviewText:
Is this game for you?

First of all, it's such a unique world and theme, it's very refreshing to come across something new..

Second, if you like logic and puzzles, if your school had IQ tests and you did well, you will definitely like this game. It doesn't insult your intelligence by telling you exactly what button to press every step of the way.

Now, if you are afraid of failure or you need an XP progress bar or the sound of collecting coins in order to make you feel better and keep you motivated then this might not be the game for you.

Some very clever puzzles and other cool things like when you put together a motorcycle out of parts of other signs.


EDIT: WOW! There is a hint system now with the last update. So, seriously, no excuses now, go finish the game :)

reviewText: This is not a good game at all. Very basic stuff. Only positive is the music really. I have played Limbo, I have played Type:Rider...those games have something to offer, and this game doesn't. Graphics are way too simplistic here, animations are laughable, the controls are EXTREMELY laggy and the gameplay is just boring stuff. Physics aren't that great either.\n\nI mean no disrespect to the dev of Sign motion, but long story short, this is kind of like a student project with no polish. At the very best, it is an early prototype of a game that could, conceptually, turn out to be good. As such, in its current guise, Sign Motion is not worth playing at all, whatever the price of the game may be (even if it is free). This is the kind of stuff budding gamemakers make just to get experience, NOT to sell it to the public for a profit.

reviewText: The game is good for what it was designed to be; a puzzle platformer.\n\nDon't expect to play through the game in one sitting, you will play it and sometimes you will be frustrated and hate it. Then you will continue until you hit another brick wall...rinse and repeat.  That is what this game is
date: and if you're the type that enjoys that kind of experience
recommended: I'd highly recommend this to you.\n\n"

reviewText: Would like to give this a positive review because it started out really fun, but it turned into the most annoying thing. I like the simple graphics and overall look of the game, it's just what it needs to look like, signs. The timelimits on the puzzles killed the little satisfaction I got after finally beating the umbrella course. Would appreciate a walkthrough because right now I can't seem to figure out what to do before the poison cloud kills me. (All I can do is get a suitcase stuck between two signs.) It doesn't always read that I want to jump so I ran into death too many times, and sometimes I just get stuck on boxes/signs. I hear rumors of a Sign Motion 2 so I hope that one fixes the few but annoying faults of this one.
